questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except?(NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery

options.label: B
options.text: It arises from the anterior aortic sinus

options.label: C
options.text: It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

options.label: D
options.text: Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.correct_answer: C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The circumflex coronary artery is actually a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. It travels along the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle, primarily supplying the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.

questions.text: IUCD can be inserted after delivery till? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery, but not between 48 hours to 6 weeks due to the high risk of expulsion during this time.

questions.text: The treatment given to the patient presenting with a history of binge alcohol intake and symptoms of convulsions, altered sensorium, and plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thiamine followed by dextrose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In alcohol-related hypoglycemia, always administer thiamine before dextrose to prevent the exacerbation of thiamine deficiency and associated complications.

questions.text: 2 handkerchiefs with blood stains are found at a crime scene. What is the most appropriate procedure for handling these items? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Place them in same plastic bag and seat it for preservation

options.label: B
options.text: Preserve in envelope or paper bag

options.label: C
options.text: Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together

options.label: D
options.text: Place them in different plastic bags and seal for preservation

questions.correct_answer: B. Preserve in envelope or paper bag
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Preserve in envelope or paper bag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When handling blood-stained items found at a crime scene, preserve them in an envelope or paper bag to allow for air circulation, and dry the stains in the shade or by air drying to prevent DNA denaturation. Avoid using plastic bags or exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat.
  • ➤ Avoid using plastic bags or exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat.

questions.text: You see these marks on the forearm of a woman who is being constantly harassed for dowry by her in-laws. What is this finding known as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hesitation cuts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hesitation cuts are superficial, parallel, and multiple cuts typically found in accessible areas like the wrist or throat, often indicating a cry for help or a practice attempt by individuals contemplating suicide.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of an old lady who sustained a fall and presented with a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Subdural Hematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Given the history of a fall and the delayed onset of neurological symptoms, a subdural hematoma (option D) is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: Preservative commonly used for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination is: ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Formalin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Formalin is the preservative of choice for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination due to its ability to maintain tissue morphology and cellular details.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson is a 60-year-old woman who underwent a Whipple's procedure for pancreatic cancer three weeks ago. She developed a fever and abdominal pain, and her surgeon suspected a postoperative complication. Which of the following complications causes maximum malnutrition? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duodenal fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ A duodenal fistula (option B) is the postoperative complication that can cause maximum malnutrition due to its disruption of nutrient absorption in the critical site of the digestive process, the duodenum.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child who weighs 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis presents to you with fever and arthralgia. There is no past history of rheumatic heart disease or features of carditis or valvular disease. How often is benzathine penicillin recommended for prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease? (Neet pg 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 5 years

options.label: B
options.text: 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years

options.label: C
options.text: 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years

options.label: D
options.text: 1200000 IU Once in 3 weeks for life

questions.correct_answer: B. 600000 IU Once in 3 weeks for 10 years
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For an 11-year-old child weighing 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis and no carditis or valvulitis, benzathine penicillin G prophylaxis should be administered at a dose of 600,000 IU every 3 weeks for a duration of 10 years (until the child turns 21 years old).

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: A woman came to OPD with a newborn who has complaints of chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The paediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lecithin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant, particularly lecithin (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the ER with menorrhagia. She mentions that her father and sister also suffer from bleeding disorders. Which of the following is likely? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Von Willebrand Disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Von Willebrand Disease is an autosomal dominant disorder presenting with bleeding symptoms like menorrhagia and is more common in females compared to Hemophilia A or B, which are X-linked recessive and primarily affect males.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress? ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stress can be conceptualized as the body's adaptive response to demands or threats. It's not just a psychological phenomenon; it has physiological correlates as well. Stressors can be external (e.g., environmental pressures) or internal (e.g., illness, or undergoing a medical procedure), and they can be short-lived (acute) or long-term (chronic).

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2117

questions.text: A woman at 30 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Which of the following is the most appropriate for this patient for prophylaxis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for both the treatment and prophylaxis of DVT during pregnancy across all trimesters due to its safety profile for both the mother and fetus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family says she has a history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor arrived at a provisional diagnosis based on the clinical features. Which of the following would be the best test to arrive at a definitive diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sestamibi scan is the best diagnostic test for localizing abnormal parathyroid glands in primary hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: Delphian lymph nodes belong to which level in neck nodes? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Level 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Delphian lymph node is categorized as Level 6 in the classification of neck lymph nodes, situated in the central compartment above the thyroid isthmus.

questions.text: Identify the sign shown in the image below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Popeye sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Popeye sign is a clinical indication of the rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon, leading to a characteristic bulging of the biceps muscle, which requires thorough clinical assessment and possibly surgical repair.

questions.text: What are the different levels of triage in emergency care? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Head neck, thoracic and abdominal triage

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Triage helps to ensure that patients receive the appropriate level of care based on their condition and the resources available. By prioritizing patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses, emergency medical personnel can provide the best possible care to the greatest number of patients in a disaster or emergency situation.

questions.text: Mid-year population is the denominator in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CDR

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The mid-year population is used as the denominator to calculate the Crude Death Rate (CDR). The CDR is calculated as the total number of deaths divided by the mid-year population, multiplied by 1,000.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. GFR (General Fertility Rate) - This option is incorrect because. It is calculated as Annual number of live births per 1000 women of childbearing age (15–49 years) mid-year population
  • • Option
  • • B. GFR (General Fertility Rate)
  • • Option C. MMR (Maternal Mortality Ratio) - This option is incorrect because the MMR is calculated as maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, not using the mid-year population as the denominator.
  • • Option
  • • C. MMR (Maternal Mortality Ratio)
  • • Option D. NMR (Neonatal Mortality Rate) - This option is incorrect because the NMR is calculated as neonatal deaths per 1,000 live births, not using the mid-year population as the denominator.
  • • Option
  • • D. NMR (Neonatal Mortality Rate)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mid-year population is the denominator used in the calculation of the Crude Death Rate (CDR), which represents the total number of deaths per 1,000 population in a given year or period.

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Cry of baby in the womb

options.label: D
options.text: Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.correct_answer: A. Cry of baby in the womb
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text: Calcium deposition is seen in which layer? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The zone of calcified cartilage is where calcium deposition occurs, leading to the hardening of cartilage and its eventual replacement by bone during the growth of long bones.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a chronic productive cough and progressive difficulty in breathing. On examination, his FEV1% is significantly reduced. Based on this finding, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) COPD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a chronic productive cough, progressive difficulty in breathing, and a significant reduction in FEV1%. It is a common cause of chronic obstructive pulmonary symptoms in older adults, particularly those with a history of smoking.

questions.text: Pencil shaped macroconidia are seen in? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichophyton

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pencil-shaped macroconidia are a distinguishing feature of the fungus Trichophyton. Trichophyton is one of the three genera of dermatophytes, which also include Microsporum and Epidermophyton.
  • • Dermatophytes cause infections known as dermatophytosis or ringworm, which affect keratinized tissues such as the skin, hair, and nails.
  • • Dermatophytosis can be classified into three species:
  • • Trichophyton: Involves skin, hair, and nails. The macroconidia are pencil-shaped, and the microconidia are round to piriform (pear-shaped). In the case of Trichophyton, the macroconidia are elongated and resemble pencils. This characteristic helps in differentiating it from other dermatophytes. Microsporum: Primarily involves skin and hair. The macroconidia are spindle-shaped and spiny, while microconidia are usually absent. Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. The macroconidia are club-shaped, and microconidia are absent.
  • • Trichophyton: Involves skin, hair, and nails. The macroconidia are pencil-shaped, and the microconidia are round to piriform (pear-shaped). In the case of Trichophyton, the macroconidia are elongated and resemble pencils. This characteristic helps in differentiating it from other dermatophytes.
  • • Trichophyton:
  • • Microsporum: Primarily involves skin and hair. The macroconidia are spindle-shaped and spiny, while microconidia are usually absent.
  • • Microsporum:
  • • Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. The macroconidia are club-shaped, and microconidia are absent.
  • • Epidermophyton:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Microsporum: The macroconidia of Microsporum are spindle-shaped and spiny, not pencil-shaped. This genus primarily affects skin and hair.
  • • Option B. Microsporum:
  • • Option C. Epidermophyton: The macroconidia of Epidermophyton are club-shaped, not pencil-shaped. This genus affects skin and nails.
  • • Option C. Epidermophyton:
  • • Option D. Clostridium: This is a genus of bacteria, not fungi, and it does not produce macroconidia. Clostridium species are known for producing spores, not conidia.
  • • Option D. Clostridium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pencil-shaped macroconidia are characteristic of Trichophyton, a genus of dermatophytes that affects skin, hair, and nails.

questions.text: Incorrect statement about choledocal cyst is: (INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Cyst is opened and drainage done

questions.correct_answer: B. Cyst is opened and drainage done
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cyst is opened and drainage done

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ While the management of choledochal cysts involves a comprehensive approach considering the risk of malignancy, the appropriate surgical intervention usually entails the complete removal of the cyst and careful reconstruction of the biliary system, not just simple drainage.

questions.text: Scenario with primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characters present, uterus and ovaries present with an image as shown. What is the likely karyotype ? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 46 XX

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary amenorrhea with normal development of secondary sexual characteristics and intact internal female reproductive organs (uterus and ovaries) generally indicates a normal female karyotype, 46 XX.

questions.text: Which muscle is typically represented by the color blue? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Extensor carpi radialis longus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Origin : It originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus. Insertion : It inserts into the base of the second metacarpal bone on the dorsal side. Action : This muscle extends and abducts the wrist. It helps in the extension of the wrist joint and also assists in radial abduction. Innervation : It's innervated by the radial nerve.
  • • Origin : It originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus.
  • • Origin
  • • Insertion : It inserts into the base of the second metacarpal bone on the dorsal side.
  • • Insertion
  • • Action : This muscle extends and abducts the wrist. It helps in the extension of the wrist joint and also assists in radial abduction.
  • • Action
  • • Innervation : It's innervated by the radial nerve.
  • • Innervation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Brachioradialis :
  • • Option B.
  • • Brachioradialis
  • • Origin : This muscle originates from the proximal two-thirds of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus. Insertion : It inserts into the lateral surface of the radius near its styloid process. Action : The primary function is to flex the elbow. However, unlike most other flexors of the elbow, which are pronators, the brachioradialis is a supinator when the forearm is pronated and a pronator when the forearm is supinated, making it a neutralizer of the forearm. Innervation : The brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve.
  • • Origin : This muscle originates from the proximal two-thirds of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus.
  • • Origin
  • • Insertion : It inserts into the lateral surface of the radius near its styloid process.
  • • Insertion
  • • Action : The primary function is to flex the elbow. However, unlike most other flexors of the elbow, which are pronators, the brachioradialis is a supinator when the forearm is pronated and a pronator when the forearm is supinated, making it a neutralizer of the forearm.
  • • Action
  • • Innervation : The brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve.
  • • Innervation
  • • Option C . Supinator :
  • • Option C
  • • Supinator
  • • Origin : The supinator muscle has a two-headed origin – one from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus (by the radial collateral ligament) and one from the proximal ulna (from the annular ligament and the supinator crest). Insertion : It wraps around the upper third of the radius. Action : As its name suggests, it supinates the forearm, meaning it rotates the forearm to turn the palm anteriorly or upwards. Innervation : It is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • • Origin : The supinator muscle has a two-headed origin – one from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus (by the radial collateral ligament) and one from the proximal ulna (from the annular ligament and the supinator crest).
  • • Origin
  • • Insertion : It wraps around the upper third of the radius.
  • • Insertion
  • • Action : As its name suggests, it supinates the forearm, meaning it rotates the forearm to turn the palm anteriorly or upwards.
  • • Action
  • • Innervation : It is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • • Innervation
  • • Option D. Flexor carpi radialis brevis :
  • • Option D.
  • • Flexor carpi radialis brevis
  • • Origin : It originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus. Insertion : It inserts into the bases of the second and third metacarpal bones. Action : This muscle flexes and abducts the wrist. Innervation : It's innervated by the median nerve.
  • • Origin : It originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • • Origin
  • • Insertion : It inserts into the bases of the second and third metacarpal bones.
  • • Insertion
  • • Action : This muscle flexes and abducts the wrist.
  • • Action
  • • Innervation : It's innervated by the median nerve.
  • • Innervation

questions.text: A man is working in an industry without wearing a helmet. A heavy hammer falls on his head due to slipping from the head of his colleague working on the top floor. The X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture of the base of the skull

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Depressed Fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A heavy object with a small striking surface, such as a hammer, typically causes a depressed fracture in the skull. ​

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension and is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Spironolactone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic, can cause severe hyperkalemia, which is characterized by tall, tented T waves, absent P waves, and widened QRS complexes on an ECG.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has ptosis and limb weakness that worsens in the evening. She was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. What is the first-line drug used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyridostigmine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The symptoms are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, a chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles. The hallmark of this condition is fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest.
  • • fluctuating muscle weakness
  • • The primary mechanism involves antibodies that attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing communication between nerves and muscles.
  • • The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine , an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. Pyridostigmine works by increasing the amount of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby enhancing communication between nerves and muscles, which helps to improve muscle strength.
  • • pyridostigmine
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used to reduce inflammation and modulate the immune system. While it can be used in myasthenia gravis, it is not the first-line treatment. It is typically considered when patients do not adequately respond to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.
  • • Option B. Prednisolone:
  • • Option C. Cyclosporine: An immunosuppressant that can be used in myasthenia gravis, particularly in patients who are not responsive to corticosteroids or those who have significant side effects from steroids. It is not a first-line treatment due to its side effect profile
  • • Option C. Cyclosporine:
  • • Option D. Plasma exchange: This is a procedure used in severe cases of myasthenia gravis or during myasthenic crisis. It rapidly reduces the level of circulating antibodies by removing them from the blood. This is not used as a first-line treatment but rather as an acute intervention.
  • • Option D. Plasma exchange:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that improves muscle strength by increasing acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: The most common organ that injures in air blast-shock wave is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lungs

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In an air blast or shock wave, the most common organs injured are the tympanic membrane (eardrums), lungs, and gastrointestinal tract (GIT), in that order. Since the tympanic membrane is not included in the given answer options, the correct answer among the available choices is the lungs, which are the second most commonly affected organ in an air blast.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. A. Kidney: Although the kidneys can be injured in an air blast, they are not the most common organ affected.
  • • Option. A. Kidney:
  • • Option. C. Bones: While fractures can occur due to the impact of an air blast, bones are not the most frequently injured structures compared to the lungs.
  • • Option. C. Bones:
  • • Option. D. Skeletal muscle : Skeletal muscle injuries can happen in an air blast, but they are not the most common type of injury.
  • • Option. D. Skeletal muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In an air blast or shock wave, the lungs are the most common organ injured among the given options, following the tympanic membrane. In contrast, the gastrointestinal tract is the most frequently affected organ in underwater blast injuries.

questions.text: Consider the following statements about sympathetic, parasympathetic, and motor nerves. Which of the following statements are true? (INICET MAY 2022) Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited. Sympathetic fibers travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain, before finally synapsing and then a shorter distance to effector organs. Parasympathetic fibers travel a shorter distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to the target organs. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The true statements are:
  • • Statement 1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body extensively, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited. Sympathetic fibers provide widespread distribution throughout the body, innervating various organs and tissues. In contrast, parasympathetic fibers have a more restricted distribution, primarily targeting the head, neck, and trunk regions.
  • • Statement 1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body extensively, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited.
  • • Statement 4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber. Motor neurons originate in the ventral horn of the spinal cord, and their axons branch out to innervate individual muscle fibers, facilitating voluntary muscle movements.
  • • Statement 4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Statement 2: Incorrect. Sympathetic fibers do not travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain before synapsing. Instead, sympathetic preganglionic fibers travel a short distance to the ganglia (which are located close to the spinal cord) and then the postganglionic fibers travel a long distance to reach the effector organs.
  • • Statement 2:
  • • Statement 3: Incorrect. Parasympathetic fibers travel a long distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to or within the target organs.
  • • Statement 3:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited to head neck and trunk

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery

options.label: D
options.text: Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence. The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.
  • • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.
  • • Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery:
  • • Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.
  • • Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency:
  • • Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.
  • • Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: In CN III palsy, which of the following is not affected? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In CN III palsy, abduction is not affected because it is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (CN VI).

questions.text: A child presented to the clinic with complaints of recurrent infection. Physical examination shows height for age < -2 SD. What is the appropriate term for the above mentioned condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stunting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the different indicators of malnutrition, specifically recognizing that height for age < -2 SD is a sign of stunting, which reflects chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: Which item is included in the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adulteration of food

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adulteration of food is included in the Concurrent List of the Indian Constitution, allowing both the central and state governments to legislate on this issue. The Union List and State List contain subjects exclusive to the Parliament and state legislatures, respectively.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kawasaki disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kawasaki disease is characterized by a persistent fever, erythematous and polymorphous rash, edema of hands and feet, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. It primarily affects children under 4 years old and can lead to serious coronary artery complications if not treated appropriately.

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.correct_answer: B. Not knowing the extent of thermal burns
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HSV2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) typically presents with painful genital vesicles and can cause painful lymphadenopathy. HSV2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is known for causing recurrent outbreaks of painful vesicular lesions in the genital area.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.
  • • Option B. Molluscum:
  • • Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.
  • • Option C.
  • • HPV:
  • • Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.
  • • Option D.
  • • HIV:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HSV2 infection is characterized by painful genital vesicles and can be associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.correct_answer: A. Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of neurocysticercosis involves administering steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs to target the larval infection, along with antiepileptic drugs to control seizures.
